position.marginalia_text: [Ele]mentoru[m], ex quibus erat composita. Quia Materia no[n] ita corrumpitur, vt penitus annihiletur; seu ad nihilum reducatur: cu[m] elementa destrui a nobis no[n] sit possibile; Sed Essentia & forma qua[m] ex mixtione susceperant, bene penitus annihilatur. Na[m] totum integrale (puta Domus) consistit ex suis partib[us] integralibus. Destructa vero, seu disiuncta vna parte a loco suo, que[m] locum prius habebat in toto, destruitur forma, siue Essentia totius Domus, et tame[n] remanent Lapides, Ligna et Fundamenta ex quibus co[n]stabat Domus. Sic etiam in proposito n[ost]ro. Nam separato humido a loco suo, que[m] habebat in conmixto elementari, tanq[uam] pars integralis in toto, et hoc per Calore[m] elevante[m] ip[su]m, et separante[m] ab alijs partibus, annihilatur penitus forma, et essentia ipsius mixti. Substantia tamen humidi non annihilatur, nec p[otest] annihilari. Sed contra. Nonne si ponamus olla[m] plena[m] aqua[m] ad igne[m], per virtute[m] caloris co[n]sumetur, ita q[uod] nihil remanebit? Certe sic. Ergo substantia eius penitus annihilatur. Respondemus: Quod Aqua habet substantia[m] valde subtilem et rara[m]. Item habet co[n]trarias qualitates penitus, qualitatibus ignis. Na[m] caliditas

marginalia.translation: [...] of the elements of which it was composed. This is because the matter is not corrupted in such a way that it is thoroughly annihilated or reduced to nothing, as it is not possible for elements to be destroyed by us. Its essence and form though, which are emerge from its mixture, are well annihilated thoroughly. For a whole integral thing consists of its integral parts. Once destroyed or one part divided from the place it previously held as part of the whole, the form is destroyed or/and the essence of the entire house. Nonetheless, the stones, wood and fundament remain what the house is made of. So it is in our proposition. For when the humiity is separated from the place it held in the elementary mixture as an integral part of the whole, when it itself is lessened through heat and separated from its other parts, the form and the essence of the mixture itself are thoroughly annihilated. Nevertheless, the substance of the humifity is not annihilated nore can it be annihilated. Quite the opposite. If we put a jar full of water into fire, isn't the water consumed by the property of heat, so that nothing remains? Certainly yes! Therefore its substance is throroughlu annihilated. We respond: The kind of substance that water as is subtle and rare. Likewise it has qualities entirely contrary to the qualities of fire. For heat [...].
